stream_context.summary: Kaze debugged a complex, intermittent crash related to a custom optimization. He then worked on redesigning a 'boring' red coin mission in the 'Divine Dino Domain' level, focusing on modeling and texturing while taking live feedback from chat. He also discussed concepts for a future ice castle level and shared numerous personal anecdotes and philosophical musings.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is completely redesigning a red coin mission in the 'Divine Dino Domain' level after playtesting revealed it was boring and had poor camera control.
development_findings.quote: This is just, we're just remaking one area of an old level because I have watched playtesters play it and I realized this area fucking sucks.

development_findings.summary: Kaze's core motivation is the challenge of creating a game that runs on original N64 hardware, rejecting modern engines like Unity to preserve this spirit.
development_findings.quote: It'd be pretty easy to do this just in like Unity or something but that's kind of taking away the whole spirit of the challenge of like making something that runs on n64.

development_findings.summary: A future level, Quest 13, is planned to be a suspenseful ice castle inspired by 'Hollow Root Keep' from his previous work, featuring a bright but cold and surreal aesthetic with white and desaturated blues.
development_findings.quote: Quest 13 is going to be an ice castle. On top of a mountain. And it's going to be very gloomy and scary and dark. Or maybe more suspenseful.

development_findings.summary: Kaze debugged a complex crash caused by his own unconventional optimization where a register (S8) was being overwritten by a different function during swimming.
development_findings.quote: I'm using a fucked up optimization that stores the current object pointer in the FP register, which is the same as the S8 register in GCC.

development_findings.summary: Kaze sources most textures from other games, but Zeina and Biobak also contribute original textures for the project.
Progress on certain technical aspects of the engine, specifically 'F3DX3 and RQIA', is dependent on decisions from an external contributor named Sauraen.
development_findings.quote: Nope, I'm still waiting for Sauraen to make the final decisions on that.

development_findings.summary: Kaze takes real-time visual feedback from his stream chat, such as adding fog and changing the texture on a moving platform to make it look more integrated into the level.
Kaze modifies level geometry in an early course to be more forgiving, consciously designing for less skilled players.
development_findings.quote: People are so bad at Mario 64. They do that. I need to move this closer.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes that arguing and debating topics, even politics, is a valuable way to learn about different perspectives and become smarter, rather than something to be avoided.
context_findings.quote: I like arguing about everything, just because when you argue with someone, you learn more about other ways of thinking, and you become smarter. It's just beneficial for everyone.

context_findings.summary: Kaze holds a complex ethical view on eating meat, believing it will be seen as a moral failing by future generations, yet he continues to do it.
context_findings.quote: Personally, I think that the people that eat meat nowadays in a few years, they will be looked at as like the worst people ever. The same way we look at Nazis or something nowadays. I still eat meat though, but I think people in the future will fucking hate me.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expresses a strong distrust of doctors based on past negative experiences, advocating for personal research but then immediately qualifying that it's bad advice for most people, revealing a nuanced stance on medical authority.
context_findings.quote: Unless you are capable of reading scientific literature and capable of doing research yourself, you should not use your common sense, you should just listen to the doctor. I reject my statement.

context_findings.summary: Kaze integrates physical exercise into his development workflow, believing it improves his focus and productivity by preventing 'brain fog'.
context_findings.quote: I generally think that doing some physical exercise, like in the middle of your 3D modeling or whatever, is good though. Because it keeps your brain fresh. It keeps you more focused. I think I'm more productive like that.

context_findings.summary: Kaze theorizes that manufacturing drama for YouTube views can be a form of performance art that holds a mirror to society, making the audience complicit.
context_findings.quote: By doing that drama and getting that many views you are showing society a mirror. You are like, it's not me that's bad, it's you guys that are bad because you guys are enabling this behavior.

biobak.summary: Biobak sometimes creates textures for the levels the team works on.
Biobak actively participates in the stream chat, engaging in banter and offering feedback, such as debating the lighting in the Wild West level.
biobak.quote: You're getting roasted by Biobak, Lila.

zeina.summary: A personal anecdote reveals a lighthearted aspect of Kaze and Zeina's relationship, where she accidentally gave him a 'military cut'.
zeina.quote: Because my wife fucked up my haircut. She was using the clippers to cut it short. And then the front thing of the clippers came off and she just kept going.

zeina.summary: Zeina contributes art assets to the project, including custom signs for the 'Tumbleweed Store,' 'Koopa Bank,' and 'Milk Bar' in the Wild West level.

key_stories.title: The S8 Register Crash
key_stories.summary: Kaze diagnosed and fixed a complex, intermittent crash caused by his own unconventional optimization conflicting with standard compiler behavior. This story highlights his low-level coding expertise and problem-solving process.
key_stories.challenge: The game was intermittently crashing when the player entered a specific area, particularly after swimming.
key_stories.process: Kaze diagnosed the issue as a register conflict. His custom optimization used the S8 register to store the object pointer, but a standard swimming-related function was overwriting that same register. He analyzed the compiled code and modified it to resolve the conflict.
key_stories.outcome: By refactoring the code to use fewer registers, Kaze successfully eliminated the conflict and fixed the crash, showcasing his deep technical expertise.
key_stories.key_quote: I'm using a fucked up optimization that stores the current object pointer. In the FP register, which is the same as the S8 register in GCC. And... This function here decides to overwrite the S8 register with some random local variable.

key_stories.title: Redesigning the Boring Red Coin Mission
key_stories.summary: After observing playtesters struggle with a boring and mechanically flawed red coin mission, Kaze decided to scrap it entirely. He is now building a replacement area from scratch, incorporating live feedback from his community to refine the visuals and design.
key_stories.challenge: An existing red coin mission was identified as 'boring' with poor camera and control mechanics after observing playtesters.
key_stories.process: Kaze decided to scrap the entire area rather than patch it. He began building a new layout from scratch in Blender, focusing on modeling, texturing, and lighting. He incorporated live feedback from his stream chat to refine the visual elements of the new platforms.
key_stories.outcome: The flawed area is being completely replaced with a new section featuring different platforming challenges and a more refined aesthetic. The process is ongoing and demonstrates an iterative, quality-focused design philosophy.
key_stories.key_quote: This is just a remake of an old level... because I have watched playtesters play it and I realized this area fucking sucks.

key_stories.title: The Haircut Incident
key_stories.summary: Kaze explains his new short haircut is the result of a mishap where his wife, Zeina, accidentally shaved a bald patch while using clippers. This story offers a lighthearted glimpse into their personal life and dynamic.
key_stories.process: His wife, Zeina, was cutting his hair with clippers when the guard accidentally came off, resulting in a bald line being shaved into his hair. To make it look even, they had to cut the rest of his hair very short.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze ended up with a very short 'military cut,' which he explains at the start of the stream, providing a humorous, personal anecdote.
key_stories.key_quote: Because my wife fucked up my haircut. She was using the clippers to cut it short. And then the front thing of the clippers came off and she just kept going.

open_questions.context: Kaze mentioned he redesigned an area because he 'watched playtesters play it and I realized this area fucking sucks.'
questions: Can you describe your playtesting process in more detail?
Who are the playtesters and how do you select them?
How do you gather and synthesize their feedback to make design decisions?
Can you give another example of a major change that came from a playtesting session?

open_questions.context: Badub is the project's composer but was not mentioned. Kaze listened to other game soundtracks for inspiration for the upcoming ice level.
questions: How does the music creation process work with Badub?
How do you communicate the desired mood and feel of a level, like the new ice castle, to him?
Does Badub play early builds of the levels to compose the music, or do you provide video/descriptions?
What is the feedback and iteration loop like for the soundtrack?

open_questions.context: Kaze stated that progress on a technical feature is stalled because he is 'still waiting for Sauraen to make the final decisions on that.'
questions: What are F3DX3 and RQIA, and what function do they serve in the game's engine?
Who is Sauraen and what is their role in the project?
What are the decisions that need to be made, and how do they impact development?

open_questions.context: Kaze mentioned a separate competition hack that he cannot release yet because 'ASA want me to wait until it's played on stream'.
questions: Who is ASA, and what is their role in the SM64 community that gives them influence over your release schedule?
How do these kinds of community expectations or dependencies affect your work and release plans?
